awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the chemical and physical variability of smoke using plume spatial gradients: analysis and parameterization for air quality and climate models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes an evaluation of observational data from three recent atmospheric chemistry field campaigns to measure pollutants in the plumes of wildfires. The observational data will used to develop and assess a new parameterization for modeling the variability in the pollutant aging processes across wildfire plumes. The new parameterization is expected to improve the predictive capability of air quality and climate models.

Recent observations suggest that gradients across a smoke plume include differences in photochemistry, aerosol composition, and aerosol size, likely driven by differences in dilution and UV radiation in different parts of the plume. By studying the differences between the plume edge/core and top/bottom, the investigators expect to provide a better understanding of the variability in aging between different plumes. The System for Atmospheric Modelling (SAM) - Aerosol Simulation Program (ASP) model, developed by Pierce and Alvarado with prior support from NSF, will be used to advance the understanding of pollution- and climate-relevant smoke aging processes. The data that will be used for this project includes: (1) the NSF-funded Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption, and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) campaign held in July-September 2018; (2) the DOE-supported Biomass Burning Observation Project (BBOP) conducted during June-October 2013; and (3) the Fire Influence on Regional to Global Environments and Air Quality (FIREX-AQ) campaign, a joint NASA/NOAA venture, that occurred in the summer of 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Smoke emissions from wild and prescribed fires are a significant source of aerosol particles to the atmosphere, greatly influencing both climate and human health. These smoke particles evolve in both their size and chemical composition within the smoke plumes, affecting the particles’ abilities to affect clouds, interact with radiation, and impact climate. Regarding chemical composition, smoke particles are made up of mostly organic molecules (organic aerosol; OA). Primary OA (emitted) may evaporate as the plume dilutes while secondary OA (formed chemically in the atmosphere) may condense to particles in the plume. It is unclear when evaporation vs. condensation is more dominant in plumes. Further, smoke particles coagulate with each other in plumes, leading to larger particles on average.

The overarching goal of this work is to better understand the smoke particle evolution in plumes. We hypothesized that smoke particle concentrations in plumes is the primary factor driving the variability in smoke-particle evolution. Aerosol mass concentrations in a plume of a small fire (think the burning of agricultural field) will dilute to concentrations 1 micrograms m-3 in seconds or minutes due to the short dilution length scale. On the other hand, the concentrations in large wildfires may remain greater than 100 micrograms m-3 or even 1000 micrograms m-3 for hours or days. Further, individual smoke plumes may have strong variability in concentrations across the plume, particularly if smoke is injected into multiple atmospheric layers. In this NSF Atmospheric Chemistry project, we used data from recent airborne field campaigns with models of particle chemistry and physics to test our hypothesis of the role of plume concentrations on smoke particle evolution as well.

We use aircraft data from the FIREX-AQ airborne field campaign to evaluate differences in evolving particle size distributions and OA between and within smoke plumes during the first several hours of aging as a function of smoke concentration (June et al., 2022). The observations show that the median particle diameter increases faster in smoke of a higher initial OA concentration (>1000 micrograms m−3, with diameter growth of over 100 nm in 8 h--despite generally having a net decrease in OA--than smoke of a lower initial OA concentration (<100 micrograms m−3), which had net increases in OA. We found that coagulation explains the majority of the observed particle size growth, with OA evaporation/condensation having a relatively minor impact on the size changes. This work builds on our work earlier in this NSF project focused on the BBOP field campaign (Hodshire et al., 2021). Further, our work in Akherati et al. (2022) on this project dives further into the OA evolution chemical mechanisms using process-based aerosol modelling and data from the WE-CAN field campaign and found that the chemical evolution is fastest in the first ~30 minutes after emission, slowing thereafter. Along with looking at variability in particle evolution between different plumes, we also investigated differences in particle evolution between different locations in the same plume. We focused on a plume during the FIREX-AQ campaign that had significant smoke near the surface and also about 2 km above the surface. About half plume is injected into the lower free troposphere (~2 km) with about half staying within the boundary layer (the surface up to just below 2 km). Our results from comparing 2 parts of the same plume are consistent with our analysis above where we compared different plumes; the diameter grows larger in the concentrated portion of the plume and OA is larger there as well. Hence, this work highlights that different parts of the same plume may have drastically different aerosol aging.

Finally, we investigated the role of plume injection height (PIH) on surface smoke concentrations and smoke climate effects in the GEOS-Chem-TOMAS model, which traditionally emits fire aerosol at the surface. The model generally underpredicts smoke in the free troposphere when smoke is emitted at the surface. Including PIH estimates from the GFAS emission inventory improves the model in most locations, but the CONUS and boreal North America regions require smoke to be injected higher than what GFAS predicts. Smoke has a much stronger cooling effect on climate with increasing PIH due to longer smoke lifetimes in the atmosphere. Hence, it is critical for chemical transport models and climate models to accurately include PIH in order to quantify smoke radiative effects.

We societally benefit from improved climate predictions. Wildfires are projected to worsen in future climates, but wildfire smoke particles cool climate, creating a negative feedback of fires on climate change. However, the evolution of smoke particles in plumes has significant--but poorly understood--impacts on their climate-relevant properties. The results of this work show that most of the variability is driving by smoke concentrations, which will guide the continued development of smoke-particle evolution schemes for climate models and a better understand of fire-smoke-climate feedbacks.
